answer_html: Note: Many other functions are possible as well, it does not even have to be a second order polynomial.
answer_latex:
\emph{Note: Many other functions are possible as well, it does not even
have to be a second order polynomial.}
hints_html:
Think about what each condition means.

The first is asking for a function value at 3 to be equal to 0.

What does the sign of the first and second derivative mean for the shape of the function?

The first derivative tells us if the function is increasing or decreasing. Since the second condition says that that the first derivative is negative at 3, function is decreasing at 3.

The second derivative tells us if the function is concave up or concave down. Since the third condition is saying that the second derivative is positive at 3, the function is concave up at 3.
hints_latex:
Think about what each condition means.

What does the sign of the first and second derivative mean for the shape
of the function?

The first derivative tells us if the function is increasing or
decreasing. Since the second condition says that that the first
derivative is negative at 3, function is decreasing at 3.

The second derivative tells us if the function is concave up or concave
down. Since the third condition is saying that the second derivative is
positive at 3, the function is concave up at 3.
hints_raw:
Think about what each condition means.

The first is asking for a function value at 3 to be equal to 0.

What does the sign of the first and second derivative mean for the shape of the function?
The first derivative tells us if the function is increasing or decreasing. Since the second condition says that that the first derivative is negative at 3, function is decreasing at 3.
The second derivative tells us if the function is concave up or concave down. Since the third condition is saying that the second derivative is positive at 3, the function is concave up at 3.
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
A simple-like parabola with a zero at three will work. The other zero one can be anywhere, for no particular reason lets make it at 5. So the function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = (x-3)(x-5) = x^{2} -8x + 15\end{aligned}\]

satisfies all three conditions.

To double check,

\[\begin{aligned} f(3) &= (3-3)(3-5) = 0 \\ f'(3) &= 2(3)-8 = -2 <0 \\ f''(3) &= 2 > 0 \end{aligned}\]

Let’s see the picture

Note: Many other functions are possible as well, it does not even have to be a second order polynomial.
sols_latex:
A simple-like parabola with a zero at three will work. The other zero
one can be anywhere, for no particular reason lets make it at 5. So the
function

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle f(x) = (x-3)(x-5) = x^{2} -8x + 15
\end{align*} satisfies all three
conditions.

To double check,

\begin{align*}
f(3) &= (3-3)(3-5) = 0 \\
f'(3) &= 2(3)-8 = -2 <0  \\
f''(3) &= 2 > 0 
\end{align*}

Let's see the picture

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/April_2013/MATH110Q2aSolnApr2013.jpg}

\emph{Note: Many other functions are possible as well, it does not even
have to be a second order polynomial.}

A simple-like parabola with a zero at three will work. The other zero one can be anywhere,  for no particular reason lets make it at 5. So the function
:<math>
\displaystyle f(x) = (x-3)(x-5) = x^{2} -8x + 15
</math>
satisfies all three conditions.

To double check,

<math>
\begin{align}
f(3) &= (3-3)(3-5) = 0 \\
f'(3) &= 2(3)-8 = -2 <0  \\
f''(3) &= 2 > 0 \\
\end{align}
</math>

statement_html:
Sketch a single function satisfying all of the listed criteria.

  1. \(\displaystyle f(3) = 0\)

  2. \(\displaystyle f'(3) < 0\)

  3. \(\displaystyle f''(3) > 0\)
statement_raw:
''Sketch a single function satisfying all of the listed criteria.''

# <math>\displaystyle f(3) = 0 </math>
# <math>\displaystyle f'(3) < 0 </math>
# <math>\displaystyle f''(3) > 0 </math>
